author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: As Smoke Darkens the Sky, the Future Becomes Clear
description: There’s nowhere to escape the harm from wildfires.
content: My father, who died of lung cancer, used to say that as soon as people inhaled their first cigarette, they immediately knew, if they weren’t in denial, that they were harming themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: George Winston, Pianist With a Soothing ‘New Age’ Sound, Dies at 74
description: His top-selling records for the Windham Hill label helped define a genre that took off in the 1970s, but his interests also included Hawaiian guitar and the Doors.
content: George Winston, who during decades when pop and rock dominated the musical landscape became a best-selling musician by playing soothing piano instrumentals in a style that was often described as new age but that he liked to call “rural folk piano,” died on Sunday in Williamsport, Pa. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Musgrave and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Former Florida Deputy Goes on Trial for Not Confronting Parkland Gunman
description: The officer who was the first on the scene is accused of child neglect for failing to move to stop the gunman as he carried out a massacre.
content: Seven months after the gunman in the Parkland, Fla., school shooting was sentenced to life in prison for murdering 14 students and three staff members, prosecutors on Wednesday began trying to convince a jury that a former sheriff’s deputy should also be held criminally responsible for not intervening to stop the massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: It’s the Perelman Performing Arts Center, But Bloomberg Gave More
description: With previously undisclosed $130 million gifts to the Perelman Performing Arts Center in Lower Manhattan and the Shed in Hudson Yards, the former mayor continues to shape the city’s arts scene.
content: It looked like it was never going to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love New Orleans Jazz
description: Many cities have rich jazz histories, but none goes back as far as New Orleans. We asked Wendell Pierce, Courtney Bryan and others what song they would play to get a friend to join the party.
content: Over the past few months, The New York Times has asked experts to answer the question, What would you play a friend to make them fall in love with jazz? We’ve covered lots of artists, instruments and musical styles — but this time we’re tackling a whole city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Pence Delivers Strong Rebuke to Trump in Campaign Announcement
description: The former vice president — and now rival — to Donald Trump gave his most aggressive criticism of his former boss, portraying him as unfit to be president.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence announced his presidential campaign in Iowa on Wednesday with a repudiation of Donald J. Trump, portraying his former boss — and now rival — as unfit for the presidency and going further than ever before in condemning the character and values of the man he loyally served for four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Wildfire Smoke Might Lead to Headaches
description: If you’re in pain, here’s how to mitigate it.
content: Breathing in wildfire smoke can cause a headache right away, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and short-term exposure to particulate matter from wildfires has been linked to an increase in emergency room visits for headaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell and Pat McCusker
title: The Marriage Proposal That Wasn’t
description: Bob Morris’s father fell in love at the end of his life with a woman who knew her limits.
content: Bob Morris could tell that something was changing with his elderly father: His car was clean, his manners had improved and he had a shine in his eyes. He had a new “lady friend.” Her name was Arlene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 7, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 7, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about Max Verstappen’s win at the Spanish Grand Prix misidentified the road George Russell used at the start of the race that allowed him to gain several places. It was the run-off area on Turn 1, not the pit lane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
title: Prince Harry Has His Say in Court After 7 Hours of Intense Questioning
description: Prince Harry ended his testimony in his trial against a newspaper group. “For my whole life, the press have misled about me and covered up their wrongdoing,” he said.
content: Prince Harry ended more than seven hours of intense, sometimes confrontational, testimony in a London courtroom on Wednesday, having put the ethics of Britain’s freewheeling tabloid press on trial even as he struggled to produce conclusive proof of lawbreaking by reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How to Keep Indoor Air Clean if You Don’t Have an Air Purifier
description: Fans and air-conditioners, if you use them right, can help.
content: An air purifier, like one that uses a HEPA filter, is the best way to improve the quality of your indoor air — but if you are staying inside to avoid wildfire smoke and don’t have access to an air filter, there are a few other things you can do to keep the air in your home as clean as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Taylor Swift and Matty Healy, Plus ‘The Idol’
description: Breaking down Ice Spice’s new feature on Swift’s “Karma” remix, the explosion in pop music documentaries and more.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: More Fish, More Whales, More Ships — and More Whale Strikes
description: More menhaden in New York waters means more whales, but also more collisions with ships. Plus, the Manhattan district attorney tosses hundreds of old convictions.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at what might have been behind the deaths of two more humpback whales off New York and New Jersey. We’ll also see why several hundred convictions are being thrown out in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Backing Saudi Deal, McIlroy Reprises His Role as PGA Tour’s Backstop
description: McIlroy, however, reiterated his lingering opposition to LIV Golf, saying: “I hate LIV. Like, I hope it goes away.”
content: Rory McIlroy is still seething, still edgy, still eager to bludgeon LIV Golf, the Saudi-backed league that he has spent much of the past year denigrating as a compromised interloper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Mike Johnston Declares Victory in Denver’s Mayoral Election
description: Mr. Johnston, a former Colorado state senator, benefited from far more outside spending than his opponent, who conceded on Tuesday night.
content: Mike Johnston, a former Colorado state senator buoyed by millions of dollars in outside spending, declared victory on Tuesday night in Denver’s mayoral election, beating out a candidate who had been vying to become the first woman to hold the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How Solar Wind Flows From the Sun Like Water From a Shower Head
description: The Parker Solar Probe is providing NASA researchers with insights into how the sun accelerates particles to a million miles per hour.
content: High-speed particles spew out of the sun like water from a shower head, scientists reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Camhi
title: For the First Time in Print, a Haunting Lost Classic
description: The enigmatic Susan Taubes wrote the coming-of-age novel “Lament for Julia” in the 1960s; 54 years after her death, its gothic splendors shine.
content: The process by which a young girl becomes a woman is often fraught with perils both immediate and nameless. Filter that through the nouveau roman, add a hefty dose of the gothic and a touch of surrealism, throw in a moribund Mitteleuropean backdrop and the looming banalities of midcentury American girlhood, and you might arrive at something resembling Susan Taubes’s novella, “Lament for Julia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Hong Kong Asks Court to Stop Protest Anthem From Circulating Online
description: Efforts to ban “Glory to Hong Kong,” a song popularized during pro-democracy protests in 2019, could set up a legal battle between tech giants and Hong Kong.
content: After “Glory to Hong Kong” emerged as the unofficial anthem of pro-democracy demonstrators in 2019, the government of Hong Kong has tried to stifle its use. It has banned the song from schools. When it was played in error last year instead of the Chinese national anthem at a rugby match in South Korea, the Hong Kong government demanded an investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Nick Corasaniti
title: Doug Burgum, Wealthy North Dakota Governor, Enters Presidential Race
description: As the leader of a deep-red state, Mr. Burgum has promoted staunchly conservative policies, signing into law a near-total ban on abortion.
content: Gov. Doug Burgum, the Republican governor of North Dakota, former software executive and billionaire, announced on Wednesday he would run for president on his economic record, entering an increasingly crowded race as the stolid candidate of business and technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: With Migrant Flights, DeSantis Shows Stoking Outrage Is the Point
description: The flights to California illustrate the broader bet Gov. Ron DeSantis has made that the animating energy in the G.O.P. has shifted from conservatism to confrontationalism.
content: Ron DeSantis’s decision to send migrants from near the Mexico border to the capital city of California is at first glance the latest in a series of escalating clashes between the Florida governor and his Democratic counterpart, Gavin Newsom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The PGA Tour’s Shocking Merger With LIV Golf, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Do Christie and Pence Make It 2016 Again? Not Yet.
description: A bigger field in the G.O.P. primary could chip away at DeSantis’s chances of overtaking Trump.
content: It’s been feeling a bit like 2016 lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: veritable
description: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word veritable has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 4 in “Springsteen Comes Alive” by Lindsay Zoladz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How to Protect Yourself From Wildfire Smoke if You’re at High Risk of Health Effects
description: When the Air Quality Index rises above 100, extra precautions can help keep you safe.
content: As wildfire smoke blankets large swaths of the eastern United States, many people are experiencing physical symptoms, like prickling, stinging eyes; a scratchy throat; a runny nose; and some coughing. For those without underlying conditions, this will largely be a passing source of irritation. “You’ll be miserable a little bit, but you’ll be able to brush it off,” said Dr. Panagis Galiatsatos, a pulmonary and critical care medicine physician at Johns Hopkins Medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim and Ahmed Al Omran
title: Saudi Arabia Relishes a Triumph That Transcends Sports
description: The deal to merge LIV Golf with the PGA Tour is a big win for the oil-rich kingdom, headlining a banner week that also includes a visit from the American secretary of state.
content: When a Saudi-backed upstart golf league began recruiting high-profile players from the top U.S. circuit, the American tour’s commissioner lamented a “foreign monarchy that is spending billions of dollars in an attempt to buy the game of golf.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russia and Saudi Arabia’s Oil Partnership Shows Strain
description: Analysts said the countries’ mutual need to keep energy prices high would help them maintain close ties, despite signs that Moscow has undercut previous deals.
content: For most of the last six years, the leaders of Russia and Saudi Arabia worked with each other to control the global oil market during times of war, pandemic and dizzying price gyrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: $1 Billion Federal Agency Seeks a Boss Who Will Show Up for Work
description: The Architect of the Capitol, a powerful and scandal-plagued agency, needs fresh leadership. But who wants the job?
content: Wanted: Motivated and versatile chief executive, preferably with engineering, architectural, academic and diplomatic skills, to manage 2,400 employees overseeing a 570-acre complex in the middle of Washington — including the U.S. Capitol, Supreme Court, Library of Congress, parks, restaurants and a major power plant. The position reports to the president, but Congress is trying to wrest control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: What Can I Do About My Daughter’s Father Showing Up Drunk?
description: When an ex returns from out of the blue with the same drinking problem but a new desire to be in his daughter’s life, a reader is unsure how best to protect her child.
content: My ex and I have a 13-year-old daughter. We never married. After we broke up nine years ago (in part because of his drinking), he left the country. I never applied for sole custody. We agreed our daughter would live with me, and he never paid for anything. He moved back recently and has been having dinner with her once a week. She’s getting used to having him in her life. The issue: Twice, he has turned up drunk. Most recently, he arrived very late — without responding to her many texts — and was sick in front of her. When I asked him to leave, we argued, and that upset my daughter a lot. (He denies he has a drinking problem; often, he denies he’s been drinking at all.) How can I help my daughter navigate this relationship?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Is Paralyzed as Far-Right Rebels Continue Mutiny Against McCarthy
description: Members of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus refused to surrender control of the floor, forcing G.O.P. leaders to scrap votes for the week and leaving the speaker facing what he conceded was “chaos.”
content: Hard-right Republicans pressed their mutiny against Speaker Kevin McCarthy into a second day on Wednesday, keeping control of the House floor in a raw display of their power that raised questions about whether the speaker could continue to govern his slim and fractious majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Support My Husband’s Career With Unpaid Work. Can I Stop?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on workplace inequities that manifest at home.
content: My husband and I work at the same university; he is a professor in the hard sciences and I’m an adjunct instructor who teaches literature and writing. I frequently edit the scientific articles and grant proposals that he and the postdoctoral researchers working under him write. I used to be happy to help him in this way, but lately I have begun to feel that this favor is just another way that the university benefits from my work — and the work of many humanities adjuncts — without fair compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: The Stars Are Shooting Again on the Tiber
description: Rome’s fabled Cinecittà movie studios are as full as they’ve ever been, as productions come for the tax incentives, high production values and Italian glamour.
content: Past the monumental entrance of Rome’s Cinecittà Studios, enormous screens tower over what is normally the movie studio’s front lawn, enclosing a sizable — and off-limits — backlot for the filmmaker Luca Guadagnino’s “Queer,” starring Daniel Craig.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Cisco Swank ‘Is Black Music. All of It.’
description: The 23-year-old pianist, drummer and rapper puts a pandemic-era spin on jazz-rap on his debut, “More Better,” and he always keeps the faith.
content: At a recent Sunday afternoon performance in Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill neighborhood, the pianist Francisco Haye sat behind a piano at Emmanuel Baptist Church, leading his quintet through a number of recognizable jazz standards. Yet they weren’t straight-ahead: Songs like “All the Things You Are,” “Little Sunflower” and “My Favorite Things” each had wrinkles — a bouncy backbeat or a near-frenetic breakdown — that made them feel fresh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Yglesias
title: It’s Great to Have a President Who Knows When to Shut Up
description: Politics at its best just isn’t necessarily all that entertaining.
content: President Biden’s communications strategy, if there was a strategy at all, during the recent debt ceiling showdown baffled allies and infuriated Democratic Party stalwarts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Angel
title: These Wheels Can Handle Sand and Surf. Grab the Sunscreen.
description: Wheelchairs with balloon-like tires are available at a growing number of U.S. beaches, giving disabled people and their families more options for fun in the sun.
content: For Linda Green James, getting onto the beach is usually top of mind when she’s planning a summer getaway with her daughter Suzi Osborne, 47, who uses a wheelchair because of a traumatic brain injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The Merger of LIV Golf and the PGA Tour: Here’s What to Know
description: The announced deal to dramatically change golf is far from complete.
content: The PGA Tour, the world’s pre-eminent professional golf league, and LIV Golf, a Saudi-funded upstart whose emergence over the past year and a half has cleaved the sport in two, have agreed to join forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein
title: Binance Moved Billions Through Two U.S. Banks, Regulators Say
description: The S.E.C. shared new details about how Binance’s accounts at Signature Bank and Silvergate Bank were used to move customer funds quickly through a web of foreign companies.
content: Binance, the giant cryptocurrency exchange accused of mishandling customer funds, used two American banks to move billions of dollars around the world, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday, detailing how huge sums of cash flowed in and out of the accounts sometimes within a span of days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Ann Hinga Klein and John Peragine
title: Iowa Building’s Flaws Were Well Documented Before Deadly Collapse
description: Residents said complaints about the apartment building in Davenport went unaddressed, and they questioned why the city did not intervene more aggressively.
content: The warnings about the old brick building on Main Street just kept coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Jodie Comer Leaves Broadway Show Because of Air Quality Concerns
description: The actress has been nominated for a Tony Award for her performance in the play “Prima Facie.”
content: The actress Jodie Comer, who has been nominated for a Tony Award for her tour-de-force performance in the one-woman show “Prima Facie,” stopped a performance on Broadway shortly after it had begun on Wednesday afternoon, citing difficulty breathing because of the wildfire smoke that has blanketed New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Squaring the Circle (The Story of Hipgnosis)’ Review: Indelible Images by Design
description: Anton Corbijn’s documentary shares anecdotes from the British design studio that devised some of the most famous album covers of the 1970s.
content: The album cover for Pink Floyd’s “Animals” is a collage that shows a pig flying over Battersea Power Station in London. Originally, it was intended to be a photograph, but controlling an inflatable pig at that height was not easy (in fact, it floated into an area where flights approach Heathrow Airport). Nor was it easy to have a man stand still after he had been set on fire, something that was done to create an image for the band’s preceding album, “Wish You Were Here.” Nor was arranging for a restless sheep to lounge on a psychiatrist’s couch in the Hawaiian surf — a photograph that ultimately constituted only a small inset on the original cover for the 10cc album “Look Hear?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Go the Distance
description: Jennifer Lee and Victor Galson create a perfect storm.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: John Beasley, Late-Blooming Actor Known for Playing Sages, Dies at 79
description: A former railroad clerk, he didn’t became a full-time actor until his 40s, but he made up for lost time in films like “Rudy” and TV shows like “Everwood.”
content: John Beasley, who left his job as a railroad clerk in his mid-40s to pursue acting full time, bringing an understated power to films like the inspirational 1993 football movie “Rudy” and television series like the WB drama “Everwood” and the TV Land comedy “The Soul Man,” died on May 30 in Omaha. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Florida Woman Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Her Neighbor
description: Susan Louise Lorincz was charged on Tuesday with manslaughter with a firearm in the shooting death of Ajike Owens.
content: A woman in Florida who was accused of fatally shooting her neighbor after a dispute involving the victim’s children was arrested on Tuesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Golf’s Antitrust Problem Just Got Bigger
description: Regulators were scrutinizing the PGA Tour even before its merger with its Saudi-funded competitor.
content: Sports leagues love competition, except against one another. The leagues make more money when they don’t have to compete for talent and audience. That, in a nutshell, seems to explain why the PGA Tour set aside its scruples about doing business with Saudi Arabia and announced on Tuesday that it intended to join forces with the Saudi-funded LIV Golf, an upstart that had paid huge sums to lure away some of the world’s top golfers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: The G.O.P. Has Drifted, but Mike Pence Is as Conservative as Ever
description: The polls say the former vice president, who announced his 2024 candidacy in a video on Wednesday, has little chance. But he is driven by his faith.
content: Mike Pence is the most conservative candidate competing for the presidency. The former vice president wants abortion banned from the point of conception. He’s the only major candidate calling for cuts to Social Security and Medicare. And he has the most hawkish foreign policy, especially on confronting Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Darfur, Blighted by Genocide, Faces a New Catastrophe: War
description: Hundreds have been killed in the western Darfur region since the nationwide conflict in Sudan began, raising fears of protracted warfare in an area already torn by decades of genocidal violence.
content: The gunmen arrived at dawn on motorcycles, horses and in cars. For hours afterward, they fired into houses, rampaged through shops and razed clinics, witnesses said, in a frenzied attack that upended life in El Geneina, a city in the Darfur region of Sudan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Can a Dance Class Free Men’s Bodies in a Place Meant to Contain Them?
description: An arts program in a California state facility disproves the idea that “nobody dances in prison,” encouraging inmates to channel their lives and emotions into movement.
content: Think of men in prison and you probably don’t think of dancing. But that’s what some at the California Institution for Men here were doing — dancing for invited guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 5 Things to Know About Doug Burgum
description: Elected governor of North Dakota in 2016 in a major upset, Mr. Burgum is seeking an even bigger one in the Republican presidential race.
content: Doug Burgum has at least a couple of things going for him: He is a sitting governor, which is the most common steppingstone to the United States presidency, and he has deep pockets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Timeline: CNN’s 18 Months of Tumult
description: The cable news network has struggled to weather a series of controversies, which culminated this week in the sudden departure of its chairman, Chris Licht, after a chaotic run at the top.
content: CNN has endured nearly two years of turmoil as the cable news network has struggled to overcome national scandals, abrupt departures, plummeting ratings and declining profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The destruction of a major dam in Ukraine.
content: The Kakhovka dam and electric plant in southern Ukraine was destroyed early yesterday morning, flooding a war zone downstream and raising the possibility of environmental and humanitarian disasters. Russia and Ukraine were quick to blame each other for the collapse, but it was not immediately clear who was responsible. Experts said a deliberate internal explosion was most likely the cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: N95 Masks Helped Protect Against the Coronavirus. They Also Work Against Wildfire Smoke.
description: Use N95, or better, masks and make sure they cover your nose and mouth.
content: Today’s the day to put that mask back on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin, Benjamin Mullin, Michael M. Grynbaum and James B. Stewart
title: Chris Licht Is Out at CNN, Leaving Network at a Crossroads
description: Mr. Licht’s turbulent time running the 24-hour news organization lasted slightly more than a year.
content: At 7 a.m. on Wednesday, as a cloud of smoke enveloped Manhattan, Chris Licht left his apartment building and strolled half a block to Central Park for a meeting with his boss, David Zaslav.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: LIV Golf Joins a Club That Will Have It as a Member
description: The PGA Tour’s merger with LIV is the perfect union of the tour’s lack of principle and LIV’s paucity of character.
content: They said it was about principles, but it was always about money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘This Land Was Made,’ Huey Newton Walks Into a Bar
description: Tori Sampson’s look at the Black Panther movement is a warm sitcom that becomes a jarring inquest into a real murder.
content: In Oakland, Calif., in 1968, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, was convicted of killing a white police officer. In 1971, after two more trials and nearly two years in prison, he was cleared of all charges. So who pulled the trigger?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Is Out of Surgery With ‘No Complications,’ Vatican Says
description: The 86-year-old pontiff had the medical procedure to treat a hernia.
content: Pope Francis was recovering from intestinal surgery on Wednesday, after a three-hour procedure to treat a hernia that had “no complications,” the Vatican said. It is the second time that Francis has been hospitalized in a little over two months, raising new concerns about his health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: These Taquitos Are an All-Night Breakfast of Champions
description: Perfect in their simplicity, chorizo and egg taquitos can be whatever you want them to be, whenever you want them.
content: The taquito! It’s a tiny dream in a tortilla — simplicity incarnate, endlessly amenable. Hardly as ubiquitous as its sibling the taco, and slightly less elaborate than the sauced enchilada, it can come smothered in queso fresco and lettuce, if that’s how you’d prefer it, or unadorned in a paper wrap, or spread atop smoking pastel plates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: David Zaslav Picked Chris Licht to Revamp CNN. Now What?
description: Mr. Zaslav, the head of Warner Bros. Discovery, must find a new leader who shares his vision for the network and can figure out its financial future.
content: The media mogul David Zaslav handpicked Chris Licht last year to run CNN, handing the reins of one of the country’s top news organizations to a longtime show producer. On Wednesday, just 13 months later, Mr. Zaslav said he was reversing course, and Mr. Licht was out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: Wildfire Smoke Blankets the East With Unhealthy Air
description: Stay indoors tonight and listen to New Orleans jazz. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Millions of people in the U.S. and Canada awoke this morning in a world of haze. Smoke from an outbreak of intense wildfires in Canada has been billowing south, polluting the air from Minnesota to Massachusetts and causing dangerous breathing conditions, especially in and around New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New York City Sues Queens Library Architects Over Lack of Accessibility
description: City officials argued that the building was not compliant with the Americans With Disabilities Act and other laws.
content: A few years back, architects designed a public library in Queens that has been lauded as one of the most stunning public buildings produced in New York in a century. But it is also rife with obstacles for people with disabilities, according to city officials who are now suing the designers for the $10 million they say it will cost to fix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Stunning Merger Angers Athletes
description: A professional golf merger is a victory for Saudi Arabia and another sign that money can overwhelm almost any other force in sports.
content: After the Saudi government created an upstart professional golf tour in 2021 to compete with the PGA — the world’s most prestigious tour, based in the U.S. — top PGA executives set out to destroy the new venture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Video and Photos Show a Tiny, Critically Endangered Porpoise Still Hanging On
description: The latest scientific survey of vaquitas, one of the planet’s most imperiled species, suggests that new conservation measures are working.
content: The world’s most endangered marine mammal, a small porpoise called the vaquita, is hanging onto existence and appears to be benefiting from new conservation measures, according to the results of a new scientific survey of the species that was made public on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Shannon Lin, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Turned Away and Left at Sea
description: How a video sent to The Times exposed what happened to migrants in Greece.
content: A few weeks ago, footage showing asylum seekers, including young children, being rounded up, taken to sea and abandoned on a raft by the Greek Coast Guard was sent to The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: From Houston to Athens, Rick Lowe Takes His Social Sculpture Global
description: The artist, known for the influential Project Row Houses in Houston, discusses music, basketball and art’s ability to improve lives.
content: In Athens more than 6,000 miles from his adoptive city of Houston, Rick Lowe is at home. Lowe first visited Greece in 2015, in advance of his participation in Documenta, the German exhibition of contemporary art, which marked its 14th installment in 2017 with the theme “Learning From Athens.” Lowe did just that, learning firsthand of the refugee crisis stoking tensions between local communities and asylum seekers arriving mainly from the Middle East and Africa. A longtime activist at home, Lowe saw this seemingly intractable circumstance abroad as a call to action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Want a Class in Leadership Styles? Look to the N.B.A. Finals.
description: Experts in leadership say the differing styles of Miami’s Jimmy Butler and Denver’s Nikola Jokic show there’s no one right way to be a leader.
content: A few weeks after Caleb Martin joined the Miami Heat, he didn’t yet have much social capital with his teammates. But he had been a backup player for most of his career who knew that it was important to get along with the stars — and Jimmy Butler, a six-time All-Star and the team’s leading scorer, was unquestionably Miami’s biggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Paranoid Style in Tucker Carlson’s Home Office
description: The low-fi “Tucker on Twitter” finds the former prime-time host at the intersection of Fox News and Fox Mulder.
content: Most of the time, it does not qualify as newsworthy to see a man in your social media feed staring into a camera, asking “What exactly happened on 9/11?” and demanding to know why the media isn’t digging for the truth about J.F.K.’s assassination. Usually, it’s just a sign that you should not have accepted so many friend requests from high school classmates you barely remember.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sunak to Talk Tech With Biden, but the War in Ukraine Is Likely to Surface
description: While economic corporation the challenges posed by artificial intelligence are on the agenda, Russia’s invasion presents immediate threats.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain began a two-day visit to Washington on Wednesday with a goal of aligning two allies on the challenges of artificial intelligence. But his meeting with President Biden will more likely be consumed by the here-and-now threat of Russia’s war on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linsey Marr
title: What Wildfire Smoke, Gas Stoves and Covid Tell Us About Our Air
description: Wildfire smoke underscores the need for better indoor air quality.
content: We just lived through a pandemic caused by a tiny virus floating in the air. Now we are experiencing wildfires that not only devastate communities and landscapes but also send out gigantic plumes of smoke that can affect millions of people downwind, as the Northeast is experiencing now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: How Long Will the Smoke Last?
description: In New York City, the hazy, unhealthy air is expected to linger through Thursday morning.
content: The worst period of hazy, unhealthy air in New York City will last from Wednesday afternoon through Thursday morning, according to a New York Times analysis of computer forecast models. The haze will most likely vary in thickness through the overnight hours and could last through the day Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Two People Fatally Shot Outside High School Graduation in Richmond
description: Five others also were shot, the authorities said, and more were hurt in the ensuing chaos. A 19-year-old suspect was arrested on murder charges.
content: Two people were fatally shot and several others were injured on Tuesday evening in a shooting outside a theater in Richmond, Va., where a high school graduation ceremony had just taken place, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Louisiana Lawmakers Pass Ban on Transition Care for Transgender Minors
description: It was unclear on Wednesday how Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, would respond to the legislation, or if his input would make a difference.
content: Louisiana lawmakers have voted to make the state the latest to prevent transgender minors from having access to gender-transition care, advancing legislation that would ban hormone treatments, puberty blockers and surgeries for young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: How a 14-Year-Old Came to Animate a Scene in ‘Across the Spider-Verse’
description: Preston Mutanga created a shot-for-shot version of the trailer with animated Lego characters. Then the producers asked him to work on the movie.
content: Early in the thrill-packed sequel “Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse,” the story takes a brief yet memorable detour into a dimension that resembles Lego building blocks and figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky, Liam Stack and Vjosa Isai
title: Wildfires Spread Smoke, and Anxiety, Across Canada to the U.S.
description: Massive plumes of smoke from hundreds of Canadian fires, enveloped millions in smoke, triggering dangerous air quality warnings in both countries and turning skies an ashen orange.
content: Canada on Wednesday was struggling to fight an extraordinary outbreak of wildfires across the country that sent smoke pouring over the border and forced millions of Canadians and Americans to stay indoors as skies darkened over large portions of both nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Wet Brain’ Review: A Vodka-Spiked Horror Show
description: The children of a severely alcoholic widower navigate his incapacity, and his legacy, in John J. Caswell Jr.’s pitch-black comedy about addiction.
content: In the escalating series of calamities that constitute Joe’s misadventures with alcohol, his middle child, Ricky, has missed a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: They Fled San Francisco. The A.I. Boom Pulled Them Back.
description: Tech entrepreneurs who left the Bay Area during the pandemic say they can’t afford to miss out on the funding, hackathons and networking of the artificial intelligence frenzy.
content: Doug Fulop’s and Jessie Fischer’s lives in Bend, Ore., were idyllic. The couple moved there last year, working remotely in a 2,400-square-foot house surrounded by trees, with easy access to skiing, mountain biking and breweries. It was an upgrade from their former apartments in San Francisco, where a stranger once entered Mr. Fulop’s home after his lock didn’t properly latch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A Crackdown on Gay Rights Is Codified
description: In Uganda, the president recently signed a punitive anti-gay law that calls for imprisonment and even the death penalty. The Times’s East Africa correspondent is covering the consequences.
content: Last month, Uganda’s president, Yoweri Museveni, signed into law one of the harshest pieces of anti-gay legislation in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: It’s Never Too Late to Travel the World With Your Best Friend
description: At 81 years old, Eleanor Hamby and Dr. Sandra Hazelip traveled from the icy shores of Antarctica to the rocky majesty of the Grand Canyon — in 80 days.
content: When Eleanor Hamby and Dr. Sandra Hazelip met more than two decades ago, it was best friends at first sight. They never imagined that, one day, their friendship would be featured on news shows, get joked about on “Saturday Night Live” and stop people in their tracks in a Tokyo train station to exclaim, “Oh my God, you’re the TikTok traveling grannies!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima
title: Disaster Upon Disaster: Flood Deepens Misery in Ukraine War Zone
description: “We were getting used to the shelling, but I’ve never seen a situation like this,” said one woman rescued in Kherson after a dam upstream was destroyed.
content: Oleksiy Kolesnik waded ashore and stood, trembling, on dry land for the first time in hours, rescued on Wednesday morning after spending the predawn sitting on top of a cabinet in his flooded living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Orange Skies and Burning Eyes as Smoke Shrouds New York City
description: New Yorkers are accustomed to dealing with weather. This was something very different.
content: The smoke from wildfires hundreds of miles north that turned New York into a scene of unsettling gloom on Wednesday arrived as if from a burning building blocks away, draping the city in a thick and otherworldly orange-gray hue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Man Charged With Spraying Police With Insecticide on Jan. 6
description: The Justice Department also charged the Long Island man with assaulting a news photographer.
content: The owner of a Long Island funeral home was charged on Wednesday with spraying an insecticide at police officers guarding the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Rory Smith
title: Lionel Messi, Soccer’s Most Coveted Free Agent, Picks Miami
description: Days after he announced he would not return to Paris St.-Germain, Messi, Argentina’s World Cup hero, said he planned his next stop to be Inter Miami of M.L.S.
content: Lionel Messi, who has captivated and to a large extent dominated global soccer for a generation, declared on Wednesday that the next stop in his glittering playing career would be the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $700,000 Homes in Texas, California and Massachusetts
description: A Craftsman-style house in Dallas, a desert retreat in Pioneertown and a two-bedroom condominium in Somerville.
content: This house is in the Junius Heights neighborhood, in a historic district with many early 20th-century homes lining the wide streets. It is within a couple of miles of a Trader Joe’s and an Aldi supermarket. Tenison Park Golf Course, which includes a tennis center and a public pool, is five minutes away. Deep Ellum, a popular dining and nightlife destination, is also nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Seeks to Unravel the Secret Mystery of Hospital Costs
description: The City Council is expected to approve a bill on Thursday that would allow New Yorkers to compare the cost of hospital procedures online.
content: New Yorkers in need of medical treatment often choose their hospitals based on a variety of factors: reputation, their practitioners’ affiliation or maybe location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 11 Zucchini Recipes Our Readers Love
description: Grilled, grated, sautéed and even caramelized: What can’t this summer squash do?
content: There are few ingredients as synonymous with summer abundance as zucchini. As the season progresses, supermarkets, farm stands and home gardens burst with this summer squash, challenging even the most proficient home cooks to keep thinking of creative ways to use it all up. So to help keep things fresh, here are 11 of New York Times Cooking readers’ favorite recipes that use this seasonal workhorse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: When Politics Saves Lives: a Good-News Story
description: The decision to fund medications to treat H.I.V.-AIDS patients in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean flew in the face of expert advice. But the U.S. did it anyway.
content: Here is something I don’t write about very often: a situation in which unpredictable, seemingly irrational politics saved millions of the poorest and most vulnerable people on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Griffin
title: I Know Why Disney Is Fighting DeSantis
description: As corporate America gets dragged into the culture wars, Disney had no choice but to take on DeSantis and defend the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: The culture wars have come for corporate America. In the days and weeks leading up to Pride Month, right-wing critics have levied boycotts and even threats of violence at Bud Light, Target and Kohl’s for merchandise and marketing campaigns affiliated with the L.G.B.T.Q. community. Even Chick-fil-A, the chicken-sandwich seller that has historically been aligned with conservative causes, drew sudden condemnation for an existing diversity, equity and inclusion policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia Markoulakis
title: Sober or in Recovery? Here’s How to Plan a Dry Wedding.
description: Organizing a wedding without alcohol is not without pitfalls: Will guests partake in mocktails and so-called functional beverages, and still have a good time? Are zero-proof spirits worth the cost?
content: A year ago, when my daughter got married, we all had to navigate through more than the usual pitfalls in wedding planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Europeans Now See Russia as an Adversary, but Not China
description: An extensive poll of 11 European countries finds citizens less eager for competition and rivalry with China than Washington — or European elites — have become.
content: When Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France recently made separate but friendly visits to China, it sparked considerable dismay among their fellow leaders in Europe and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Welcome to Zev’s Los Angeles
description: A conversation with the Los Angeles civic leader Zev Yaroslavsky, whose new memoir illuminates the last half-century in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Crypto Crackdown: Coinbase and Binance Lawsuits Shake Markets
description: The S.E.C.’s actions indicate a push to require crypto businesses offering securities to follow the same rules as traditional stock and bond exchanges.
content: In more blows to the cryptocurrency sector, two of its biggest players were sued this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission: On Monday, the agency filed charges against Binance, the world’s biggest exchange, and the next day it accused Coinbase, the only publicly listed exchange in the United States, of violating securities laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono
title: Air Quality This Week Gives U.S. a Glimpse of the World’s Air Pollution
description: Air-quality readings like the ones expected across parts of New York State on Wednesday would not be seen as particular cause for alarm in some parts of the world.
content: The dangerous haze hovering over parts of the Northeast and Midwest on Wednesday morning was highly unusual for the United States. For many people around the world, it would be somewhat normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Schools in the Northeast Cancel Recess and Close Early as Air Quality Worsens
description: As smoke continued to pollute parts of the Northeastern United States on Wednesday afternoon, many school districts kept students indoors.
content: In New York City and several large cities across the state, all outdoor activities and field trips were canceled for students on Wednesday as Gov. Kathy Hochul strongly urged districts “who have not yet done so to follow suit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: ‘Hollywood Dreams & Nightmares’ Review: Steady Krueger
description: In a new documentary, Robert Englund wants you to know he’s more than the face of Freddy Krueger.
content: Like a 10-page diner menu, an excessive determination is at play in “Hollywood Dreams & Nightmares: The Robert Englund Story,” a vexing documentary about Robert Englund, who even horror haters will recognize as the guy who played Freddy Krueger in the “Nightmare on Elm Street” films.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New York City’s air was ‘very unhealthy,’ the mayor said.
description: With air quality expected to deteriorate through the day Wednesday, Mayor Eric Adams said public schools would not offer outdoor activities.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said in a news release late Tuesday that by 10 p.m. air quality in parts of New York City had become “very unhealthy,” rising to 218 on the Environmental Protection Agency’s Air Quality Index.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘No One Is More Dangerous Than a Man With Nothing to Lose’: 8 Times Writers on Chris Christie
description: The former New Jersey governor may affect the race. But can he win it?
content: As Republican candidates enter the race for their party’s 2024 presidential nomination, Times columnists, Opinion writers and others will assess their strengths and weaknesses with a scorecard. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of receiving the party’s nomination next summer. This entry assesses Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mya Frazier
title: The High Cost of Bad Credit
description: Desperate to improve their ratings, Americans now spend billions on “credit repair” — but the industry often can’t deliver on its promises.
content: When Taqwanna Clark went to buy a video camera at Fry’s Electronics in Houston, she asked if they had a layaway plan. The cashier instead handed her an application for a store credit card. She applied. “Instantly, it came back declined — like, No!” she says. “Denied, denied — you know, your credit is not good enough.” Clark was 30 and working as a security guard at the Port of Houston. On weekends, she performed as a rapper in the local club scene, under the name T-Baby. She wanted the camera to shoot music videos, to promote her music career. “If I can’t afford a $200 camera,” she recalls thinking, “then I’m in a bad way with this credit thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Grand Jury in Florida Has Role in Documents Case
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 7, 2023.
content: “It is like the guy berating an umpire for missed calls from the cheap seats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 5 Things to Know About Mike Pence
description: Mr. Pence is a once-loyal vice president who became a target of Trump supporters, and an evangelical Christian whose faith drives his hard-line opposition to abortion.
content: Over the past eight years, Mike Pence has gone from being a skeptic of Donald J. Trump to his doggedly loyal vice president to the target of his strongest supporters during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. Now he is one of a growing number of Mr. Trump’s opponents in the Republican presidential primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Apple Knows You Didn’t Mean to Type ‘Ducking’
description: Newly announced modifications to the autocorrect feature used on iPhones will better understand a word’s context in a text message, saving users some blushes.
content: Apple on Monday announced an updated autocorrect function that aims to more accurately reflect users’ intended word choices, pleasing customers whose attempts to swear in texts have long been replaced with “duck” or “ducking” (and freeing innocent waterfowl from their unfortunate association with an obscenity).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Pat Cooper, Comedian of Outrage, Is Dead at 93
description: He built his act on making fun of his Italian American heritage. He later publicly insulted stars he had worked with, including Frank Sinatra and Howard Stern.
content: Pat Cooper, the stand-up comic who made outrage his act, progressing from mocking Italian American families like his own to publicly insulting celebrities like Frank Sinatra and Howard Stern, died on Tuesday night at his home in Las Vegas. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why You Can’t Really Be a Gardener Without Mindfulness
description: In the last volume of his memoir trilogy, Marc Hamer explains why a garden is not just a place of work — it’s also a place of worship.
content: Marc Hamer was “the gardener,” someone who — for a portion of each day, over a career’s worth of years — knelt for hire, often pulling weeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Ackerman
title: What Owls’ Silent Flight Tells Us About the World
description: Being quiet and inconspicuous has its advantages.
content: When the first lucky observers spotted Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl, in Central Park in February, they knew they were seeing an owl. Owls are probably the most easily identified birds, with their upright bodies, big round heads and enormous front-facing eyes — it’s hard for even young children to mistake them for any other creature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Paul Sonne and Victoria Kim
title: Floodwaters Engulf Front Line in Ukraine War
description: As rescue efforts plucked people from rooftops, and offered fresh water and shelter, Turkey’s president called for an international investigation into what caused a dam to fail.
content: KHERSON, Ukraine — Thousands of people escaped inundated homes in southern Ukraine on Wednesday, including many rescued from rooftops, a day after the destruction of the Kakhovka dam gave rise to another humanitarian disaster along the front lines of the 15-month war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Double Strawberry Shortcakes, on Repeat All Summer
description: Melissa Clark’s genius technique ensures fluffy — not soggy — berry-studded biscuits.
content: Hello there! I’m Mia, the newsletter editor here at New York Times Cooking, filling in for Melissa Clark. As you might expect, my job puts me at the center of thousands (and thousands) of excellent recipes, and many of them wedge themselves deeply in my brain, tacky bits of toffee stuck to my subconscious. Right now, these double strawberry shortcakes (above) will not let me go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Los Angeles Times to Cut More Than 10% of Newsroom
description: “The restructuring stems from the same persistent economic headwinds facing news media across the country,” the executive editor said in an email to the staff.
content: The Los Angeles Times is cutting more than 10 percent of its newsroom jobs, its executive editor, Kevin Merida, said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Carl Lewis Hopes to Lead ‘Speed City’ to a National Title
description: Lewis, the American track and field legend, is now head coach of the sport at the University of Houston. He expects excellence, and an N.C.A.A. Division I team title.
content: When Carl Lewis left the University of Houston over 40 years ago, he was 19, the indoor world-record holder in the long jump and one of the best sprinters on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: As the Suburbs Go, So Goes America
description: America is undergoing a racial and ethnic upheaval that will profoundly shape election outcomes.
content: Over the past half century, the percentage of Black Americans living in the nation’s suburbs has doubled, a shift that is changing the balance of political power in key regions of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Satoshi Kuwata of Setchu Wins the LVMH Prize, Fashion’s Biggest Young Designer Award
description: The brand celebrates cross-cultural communication and bridge-building.
content: Satoshi Kuwata, the Japanese designer and founder of Setchu, a brand that bridges East and West, craft and transformation, has won the 2023 LVMH Prize for Young Designers, the largest and most prestigious such award in the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Is It Safe to Go for a Run in Wildfire Smoke?
description: Wednesday is Global Running Day, but experts advise against outdoor exercise in areas affected by smoke from the wildfires in Canada.
content: Yes, it’s Global Running Day. No, you probably shouldn’t go for a run today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: When ‘Regime Change’ Means Returning America to an Idealized Past
description: The new book by the political scientist Patrick J. Deneen proposes to replace the country’s “invasive progressive tyranny” with conservative rule in the name of the “common good.”
content: It isn’t easy being Patrick J. Deneen. In 2018, he published “Why Liberalism Failed,” a scathing and sweeping critique that was attentively discussed by the very people (establishment politicians, Ivy League academics, mainstream journalists) he depicted as too ruthless and arrogant to care about the problems ravaging the country: ecological degradation, economic devastation, social isolation, deaths of despair. Magazine sections were given over to debating Deneen’s thesis; Barack Obama promoted the book on his reading list. Multiple articles in this newspaper parsed his argument, precisely because it voiced some of the discontent that had helped propel Donald J. Trump into the highest office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: How Sam Altman Stormed Washington to Set the A.I. Agenda
description: The chief executive of OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, has met with at least 100 U.S. lawmakers in recent months. He has also taken his show abroad.
content: Weeks after OpenAI released its ChatGPT chatbot last year, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence start-up, launched a lobbying blitz in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman, William K. Rashbaum and Glenn Thrush
title: Prosecutors Tell Trump’s Legal Team He Is a Target of Investigation
description: The notice from the office of the special counsel Jack Smith suggested that an indictment was on the horizon in the investigation into the former president’s handling of classified documents.
content: Federal prosecutors have informed the legal team for former President Donald J. Trump that he is a target of their investigation into his handling of classified documents after he left office, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: The Republican Silly Season Has Begun
description: Raise your hand if your name’s not Trump.
content: Whenever I want to put myself to sleep at night, I run through the names of all the former vice presidents. OK, sorta peculiar. It might be time for a break. Maybe I’ll just try making a list of Republican candidates for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘It just keeps coming’: Rescuers reach an inundated neighborhood to find fetid water and exhausted people.
description: Low-lying areas of Kherson were a panorama of water and floating debris. One man stood on a cabinet in his living room waiting for hours for help.
content: KHERSON, Ukraine — Oleksiy Kolesnik waded ashore and stood, trembling, on dry land for the first time in hours, rescued after spending the predawn sitting on top of a cabinet in his flooded living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman and Tyler Kepner
title: Yankees Game Postponed Because of ‘Hazardous’ Air Quality
description: A night after having teams play through adverse conditions, Major League Baseball pulled the plug on two games. A W.N.B.A. game in Brooklyn was also postponed.
content: With air quality in the Bronx registering at “hazardous” levels because of smoke from wildfires in Canada, Major League Baseball postponed a game between the Yankees and the Chicago White Sox, which had been scheduled for 7:05 p.m. on Wednesday at Yankee Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: PGA Tour and LIV Golf Agree to Alliance, Ending Golf’s Bitter Fight
description: In a stunning announcement, the tour, along with the DP World Tour and Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, said the rivals had agreed to create a “new, collectively owned, for-profit entity.”
content: The PGA Tour, the dominant force in men’s professional golf for generations, and LIV Golf, which made its debut just last year and is backed by hundreds of millions of dollars in Saudi money, will together form an industry powerhouse that is expected to transform the sport, executives announced Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘No Next Steps’ as of Yet for Aaron Judge’s Toe Injury
description: Judge, the slugging Yankees outfielder, got an injection to aid healing in his sprained toe. He will be out at least 10 days.
content: Officially, at least, the Yankees will be without Aaron Judge for at least a week after formally placing him on the injured list Wednesday with a sprain of the big toe on his right foot. But Judge — who hurt himself on a leaping catch that carried him through the right field fence at Dodger Stadium on Saturday — has no actual timeline for returning to the active roster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Remembering a Massacre That China Keeps Trying to Erase
description: Tiananmen is caught in a larger “struggle of memory against forgetting.”
content: In all my decades of reporting, one of my most searing experiences came in 1989 in Beijing when I watched the Chinese People’s Liberation Army unleash weapons of war on throngs of unarmed pro-democracy protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: A Multi-Season Celebration of the Martha Graham Company at 100
description: Starting in fall, the company will present a three-year celebration featuring Graham classics and a new work by Jamar Roberts.
content: A documentary, a coffee-table book, an international tour and an opera partnership will be some of the many homages to the Martha Graham Dance Company as it celebrates its 100th anniversary, starting this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Age, and His Achievements
description: Readers discuss President Biden’s age and his accomplishments. Also: The PGA-LIV golf merger; self-policing in Brooklyn.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Truth About ‘Nature’s Ozempic’
description: What experts know about berberine, the chemical compound purported to help induce weight loss.
content: As the demand for Ozempic — the injectable diabetes medication that has become coveted for inducing weight loss — continues to intensify, people across TikTok are posting about alternatives. Some gush about other diabetes drugs, like Mounjaro; some tout so-called “generic” Ozempic from compounding pharmacies. And some are trumpeting what they claim is a cheaper option, readily available in pharmacies and online: “nature’s Ozempic,” better known as berberine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Kilauea Erupts in Hawaii With ‘Incandescent’ Glow
description: The volcano on the Big Island gave hints in the past month that an eruption might be imminent.
content: Kilauea, the youngest and most active volcano on the Big Island of Hawaii, erupted early Wednesday morning, officials said, sending fountains of lava spewing skyward before pooling and spreading across its summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Smoke Leads to Cancellations of ‘Hamilton’ and ‘Camelot’ on Broadway and ‘Hamlet’ in Central Park
description: The poor air quality sent a star offstage mid-play and forced the cancellation of one of Broadway’s most popular musicals, a classic revival, and Shakespeare in the Park.
content: As smoke from Canadian wildfires blanketed New York City and seeped into theaters, alarming both ticket holders and performers, the Broadway productions of “Hamilton” and “Camelot,” as well as a Free Shakespeare in the Park production of “Hamlet,” canceled performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: The Tribeca Festival Has a Story to Tell
description: Documentaries about siblings and baseball are among the standouts in the film slate of an event that encompasses a lot more than movies.
content: Every spring, the Tribeca Festival returns to Lower Manhattan with a bulky mixed bag of creative programming. Looking for virtual reality? Concerts? Video games? Podcast tapings? The event, which dropped “film” from its name in 2021, lassos together all its media with the key word storytelling — a buzzy, often branded term. Past attendees of the festival might recall Robert De Niro, one of its founders, rapping, “I’ve got a story to tell,” at the start of a bouncy, AT&T-sponsored Tribeca trailer that preceded screenings for half a dozen years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Crypto Firms Start Looking Abroad as U.S. Cracks Down
description: As the country becomes one of the world’s strictest crypto regulators, companies are exploring plans to expand internationally and possibly leave entirely.
content: The wave of government enforcement against cryptocurrency companies is beginning to remake the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Universal Says On-Demand Film Strategy Has Increased Audience
description: The studio let viewers rent or buy movies earlier for a higher price. This made more than $1 billion in less than three years, with nearly no decrease in box-office sales.
content: In 2020, at the height of the pandemic, Universal Pictures and its art-house sibling, Focus Features, set off alarm bells in Hollywood by ending the long-held practice of giving theaters an exclusive window of about 90 days to play new movies. Instead, their movies, which have since included “Jurassic World: Dominion,” “Belfast,” “Cocaine Bear” and “M3gan,” would become available for digital rental or purchase — at a higher price — after as little as 17 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Turkey’s Lira Falls to New Low as a New Economic Policy Forms
description: The lira plunged 7 percent against the U.S. dollar, as a new finance minister promising “rational” economic policy takes charge
content: The value of the Turkish lira as measured in dollars plunged Wednesday by more than 7 percent to a record low, signaling a potential shift in the government’s economic policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How to Keep Pets Safe From Wildfire Smoke
description: Birds and pugs are particularly at risk of complications from poor-quality air.
content: The guidance that goes for humans also applies to pets: When the air is intensely polluted, limit the time your pet is outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Prince Harry, Phone Hacking Avenger
description: He has his own supersuit for the trial.
content: Since he and his wife, Meghan Markle, announced their decision in 2020 to step back as working royals and leave Britain, many versions of Prince Harry have been offered for public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Defends Migrant Flights and Takes a Swipe at California
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida criticized immigration policies in his first visit to the border since beginning his presidential bid.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Wednesday defended his state’s sending three dozen Latin American migrants to Sacramento on recent charter flights from the border, saying California had “incentivized” illegal immigration and ought to pay the costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Senators Say TikTok May Have Misled Congress on Handling of U.S. User Data
description: Two senators sent a letter to TikTok’s C.E.O. with questions about how user data may be stored and seen in China after new reports in May.
content: Two senators sent a letter to TikTok’s chief executive on Tuesday, accusing the company of making misleading claims to Congress around how it stores and handles American user data, and demanding answers to more than a dozen questions by the end of next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: André Leon Talley’s ‘Sanctuary’ in White Plains, N.Y., Is for Sale
description: The fashion icon, who died last year, loved to escape the city and deal with the world from his front porch.
content: For the last 18 years of his life, André Leon Talley — Vogue’s pioneering creative director — lived in a stately center-hall colonial in White Plains, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Mayor Adams and the Brooklyn Apartment He Just Can’t Quit
description: Despite Mayor Eric Adams’s multiple claims that he had sold an apartment to an ex-girlfriend, he filed financial disclosure forms showing he still owns it.
content: As Eric Adams ran for mayor of New York City, questions arose about a Brooklyn apartment that he seemed to own, even though he said he had transferred it to his former girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Megan Specia
title: What We Learned From Prince Harry’s Second Day of Testimony
description: Harry’s testimony was part of the lawsuit that he and three other plaintiffs have brought against three Mirror titles. The newspaper group has denied wrongdoing.
content: Taking the stand in an extraordinary case against a trio of British tabloids, Prince Harry was grilled during more than seven hours of testimony on Tuesday and Wednesday as lawyers for the Mirror Group Newspapers tried to argue that he had no solid evidence that its journalists had hacked his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Kennedy
title: The Truth Is, Many Americans Just Don’t Want Black People to Get Ahead
description: That racial affirmative action in university admissions and elsewhere has survived for so long is remarkable given the powerful forces arrayed against it.
content: As we await a Supreme Court ruling that is likely to restrict, if not prohibit, crediting racial identity as a plus in competitions for selection to institutions of higher education, it is worth recalling a sobering feature of the racial history of the United States: Every major step undertaken to advance African Americans and to redress the consequences of racial subordination has been met with charges of “reverse discrimination” and unfair “preference.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Yes, We’re in an L.G.B.T.Q. State of Emergency
description: This year, there is a pall over Pride.
content: This year there is a pall over Pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: ‘Never Seen Pizza Boxes at a Wake Before’: Mourning a N.Y. Pizza Legend
description: In a city full of great pizza, Andrew Bellucci was New York’s “original pizza nerd.” After he died suddenly, admirers gathered to remember his wild life.
content: Some people are born into royalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Levin
title: Midland Park, N.J.: A ‘Forever Town’ Where You ‘Buy a House and Stay’
description: The Bergen County borough has an unhurried pace and a multigenerational flavor, because many who were raised there never want to leave.
content: In Midland Park, N.J., a 199-year-old mill that gave rise to a silk-manufacturing industry houses antiques stores and gift shops. The miniature windmill outside the brick municipal building evokes a Dutch heritage still in evidence. Nine houses of worship continue a tradition of churchgoing in the 1.5-square-mile borough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Easy Lemon Tart Has a Timesaving Twist
description: A press-in-the-pan shortbread crust and an easy lemon curd filling make this stunning pastry a snap to bake.
content: One August, when I was 10 years old and vacationing with my family in a village in Provence, we decided to try lemon tarts from all the patisseries within a 20-minute drive. Every day, we’d pick up our sample to rigorously evaluate its merits and flaws. Was the pastry as crisp and crumbly as a cookie? Was the curd silky smooth, yet sharp enough to make you squint before the buttery sweetness hit?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justices Thomas and Alito Delay Release of Financial Disclosures
description: The justices asked for extensions to file annual forms that detail gifts, travel and real estate holdings.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas delayed releasing his annual financial disclosure form on Wednesday after recent revelations cast scrutiny on his travel, gifts and real estate dealings with a conservative billionaire donor from Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Is a ‘Beige Flag’?
description: On TikTok, the term is being used to describe romantic partners’ weird habits that are less than a deal breaker, but not exactly a plus, either.
content: To sort through the chaos of modern dating, some taxonomically minded singles apply a color-coded system to potential partners. Red flags are behaviors to avoid (deceit, poor dental hygiene). Green flags are go-ahead signs (honesty, owning floss).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Saudi Arabia’s Golf Deal Bolsters Its Geopolitical Ambitions
description: An agreement to merge LIV Golf with the PGA Tour is the latest step in the kingdom’s push to become a global force beyond oil.
content: The shock news that the PGA Tour plans to join forces with LIV Golf, the upstart circuit that it has spent the past year feuding with, rattled the normally staid world of golf. But the ramifications extend far beyond putting greens and 9-irons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Her Symptoms Suggested Long Covid. But Was That Too Obvious?
description: Doctors make assumptions about a case — and those assumptions can sometimes cloud their judgment.
content: The 61-year-old woman lifted the laundry basket, then grimly eyed the steps up from the basement. The climb seemed to get tougher every day. Before she was even halfway up, she could feel her racing heart and hear her ragged, rapid breathing. She gripped the wooden handrail in case she started to feel lightheaded again. Once she made it up to the main floor of her home, she dropped her burden and practically fell into the soft embrace of her living-room sofa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Defendant in Rwanda Genocide Found Unfit to Stand Trial
description: Judges at a special U.N. tribunal said they would create a procedure to allow them to hear evidence in the case against Félicien Kabuga, who has dementia, without the possibility of a conviction.
content: THE HAGUE — United Nations judges have declared a defendant in the Rwandan genocide unfit to continue standing trial because he has dementia but said that they would establish a procedure to hear evidence without the possibility of convicting him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: ‘The Ultimatum: Queer Love’ Is a TV Rarity With Familiar Drama
description: Netflix’s latest dating reality show hit, which wrapped up on Wednesday, broke ground by focusing exclusively on queer and nonbinary couples.
content: The finale of Netflix’s latest dating show hit, “The Ultimatum: Queer Love,” arrived on Wednesday after weeks of partner swapping that amounted to a milestone in romantic reality television: The first of the genre’s marriage contests that focused exclusively on queer couples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Joe Rennison
title: A $1 Trillion Borrowing Binge Looms After Debt Limit Standoff
description: The government has avoided default, but the effects of the debt-ceiling brinkmanship may still ripple across the economy.
content: The United States narrowly avoided a default when President Biden signed legislation on Saturday that allowed the Treasury Department, which was perilously close to running out of cash, permission to borrow more money to pay the nation’s bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Do People Lose Their Religion? More Than 7,000 Readers Shared Their Stories.
description: For some, faith is malleable.
content: “Nones” — the term of art for those who say they have no particular religious affiliation — is an unsatisfying label. I’m not the first to notice that it sounds like “nuns” when said aloud, and that, as a result, it can confuse people who aren’t steeped in sociological jargon. But more crucially, “nones” obscures the diversity of backgrounds and beliefs among the millions of Americans who fall into this very broad category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Dangerous Haze Across North America
description: Also, evacuations from flooding in Ukraine.
content: At least 400 wildfires burning across Canada have triggered air pollution warnings across North America. The smoke hovered over major cities in Canada and the northern U.S., blotting out the sun and bringing home the realities of climate change for people who have rarely experienced the effects of forest fires firsthand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King and Gioncarlo Valentine
title: As the Tonys Head Uptown, Step Inside the United Palace ‘Dream World’
description: The ceremony honoring Broadway’s top shows and performers will take place at the majestic former “Wonder Theater” in Washington Heights.
content: Nearly eight miles north of Times Square, the United Palace in Washington Heights is a dazzling remnant of a golden age of cinema. On Sunday, it will provide the backdrop for Broadway’s biggest night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Eli Murray
title: The Major Supreme Court Decisions in 2023
description: How the court’s 6-to-3 conservative majority is ruling this term after its lurch to the right a year ago in blockbuster decisions on abortion, guns, religion and climate change.
content: How the court’s 6-to-3 conservative majority is ruling this term after its lurch to the right a year ago in blockbuster decisions on abortion, guns, religion and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wildfires Are Intensifying. Here’s How to Protect Your Health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: GWS-OVERNIGHT-OATS-RECIPE
source.name: The New York Times

title: 47 Books for Summer
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bolognese Recipe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Dong, Bea Malsky, Matthew Bloch, Martín González Gómez, Judson Jones and John-Michael Murphy
title: Maps: Tracking Smoke and Air Quality From Canadian Fires
description: See an hourly forecast of where smoke from the Canadian wildfires is traveling across the United States.
content: See an hourly forecast of where smoke from the Canadian wildfires is traveling across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How The Legend of Zelda Changed the Game
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Midland Park, N.J.
description: The Bergen County borough has an unhurried pace and a multigenerational flavor, because many who were raised there never want to leave.
content: The Bergen County borough has an unhurried pace and a multigenerational flavor, because many who were raised there never want to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Two Killed in Shooting After High School Graduation in Richmond, Va.
description: The gunfire, which left five other people injured, sparked chaos after Huguenot High School’s ceremony. A 19-year-old man was in custody.
content: The gunfire, which left five other people injured, sparked chaos after Huguenot High School’s ceremony. A 19-year-old man was in custody.
source.name: The New York Times
